Graphical abstract SEI formed on hard carbon anode, including its components, structure, and evolution, critically affects SIBs operation, thus exploring the relationship between electrolytes and SEI formation mechanism to rationally design SEI is essential. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have great potential to be the next major energy storage devices due to their obvious advantages and developing advanced electrodes and electrolytes is urgently necessary to promote its future industrialization. However, hard carbon as a state-of-the-art anode of SIBs still suffers from the low initial Coulomb efficiency and unsatisfactory rate capability, which could be improved by forming desirable solid electrolyte interphases (SEI) to some extent. Indeed, the chemistry and morphology of these interfacial layers are fundamental parameters affecting the overall battery operation, and optimizing the electrolyte to dictate the quality of SEI on hard carbon is a key strategy. Hence, this review summarizes the recent research on SEI design by electrolyte manipulation from solvents, salts, and additives. It also presents some potential mechanisms of SEI formation in various electrolyte systems. Besides, the current advanced characterization techniques for electrolyte and SEI structure analyses have been comprehensively discussed. Lastly, current challenges and future perspectives of SEI formation on hard carbon anode for SIBs are provided from the viewpoints of its compositions, evolution processes, structures, and characterization techniques, which will promote SEI efficient manipulation and improve the performance of hard carbon, and further contribute to the development of SIBs. Keywords SEI Electrolyte optimization Hard carbon Electrochemical performance Sodium-ion batteries 1 Introduction The rechargeable energy storage technology is vital in the process of energy conversion and transportation since it is beneficial to overcome the practical obstacles of intermittent supply and regional defects for renewable clean sources such as solar energy and wind power [1]. Thus, the application of rechargeable energy storage devices hugely alleviates the dependence on fossil fuels. Generally, secondary batteries are regarded as the major energy storage devices in terms of meeting daily energy consumption and benefiting environmental protection [2,3]. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), the representative of secondary batteries, have conquered the energy storage market due to their outstanding performance such as high energy density and long cycle life [4,5]. Nevertheless, sustainable development has been hampered by limited lithium resources and uneven distribution, as shown in Table 1 . Besides, the demand for energy consumption is growing rapidly. It is imperative to seek other alternative energy storage devices to meet the energy demand. Fortunately, with a similar work principle to that of LIBs, sodium-ion battery is considered to be the most potent competitor among green energy devices at its advantages of abundant sodium, low cost, and excellent energy storage performance [6,7]. Researchers have focused extensively on the improvement of the electrochemical performance of SIBs by exploring multiple electrodes and electrolytes [1,8]. Up to now, tremendous attempts have been devoted to studying anode materials, especially carbonaceous materials have aroused increasing attention by virtue of facile synthesis and bountiful supply. Typically, the commonly used carbonaceous materials include amorphous carbon and graphite. Amorphous carbon, according to whether it is graphitized at a high temperature or not, can be classified into soft carbon and hard carbon (HC) [11]. Among those materials, HC is composed of disordered graphitic layers, randomly oriented graphitized-like microdomains, abundant voids, or pores. This unique structure of HC material provides diverse types of storage sites to accommodate a large number of Na+ ions and prevents volume expansion [12,13]. Moreover, HC material has a feature of low average redox potential and exhibits a low-voltage plateau (<0.1 V) corresponding to a majority of capacity in SIBs [14]. Thereby, HC as an efficient insertion host can deliver considerable reversible capacity and maintain cyclic stability [15]. Whereas, HC anodes applied in SIBs still have drawbacks to overcome. For instance, the sodium storage mechanism of HC anode is not fully understood owing to the complex HC structure [16]. Besides, the low initial Coulomb efficiency (ICE) needs to be improved due to substantial irreversible consumption of Na+ ions such as the SEI establishment and other side reactions [17]. The unsatisfactory rate capability also calls for further enhancement [18,19]. Electrolyte, as a dominant part of the battery, is extremely crucial to the overall electrochemical performance of SIBs. A desirable electrolyte should have high ionic conductivity, wide electrochemical stable voltage range, chemical and thermal stabilities, and facilitate the functional SEI formation [8,20]. It is widely accepted that the intrinsic electrolyte properties are determined by electrolyte constituents, in turn directly impacting the operation of batteries. For instance, a suitable solvent should possess a specific solubility, designed to dissolve electrolyte salt while minimizing the SEI layer dissolution. Furthermore, that solvent molecules participate in the construction of the solvation shell significantly affects Na+ ion diffusion kinetics and later reactions on the HC anode surface [21]. The electrolyte salts employed in SIBs consist of Na+ ions and anionic groups. Systematic investigations confirm that the salt concentration and the type of salt anion largely influence the characteristics of electrolyte [22]. Particularly, different anionic groups induce different reactions, and further distinct SEIs formed. Moreover, adding a small amount of additive to achieve various performance enhancements has been extensively carried out. For example, the versatile electrolyte additive effectively regulates the interfacial chemistry since the additive has a Fermi energy laying between the HOMO (highest occupied molecular orbital) and LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) of electrolyte salts and solvents. Thus, additives would be preferentially reduced or oxidized at the surface of electrode, resulting in a durable and protective SEI/CEI (cathode electrolyte interphase) layer [23]. Other functions, such as extending the electrochemical window and reducing the flammability of electrolyte, can be realized by introducing the appropriate additive [24,25]. Among various electrolyte systems of SIBs, organic electrolytes, which involve either ether or ester solvent, salt, and additive, are regarded as the preferred option compared to other kinds of electrolytes [26–29]. The emergence of SEI is ascribed to the irreversible and complex interphase reactions between electrolyte and electrode, then insoluble products of reactions deposit on the anode surface. An ideal SEI layer, with an integral and uniform coverage and satisfactory stability, insulates electrons and is impermeable to solvent molecules but effectively conducts Na+ ions [30,31]. Thus, SEI is significant in separating the electrode and the electrolyte to prevent more reactions during later cycling. Otherwise, continuous depletion of the limited electrolyte and Na+ ions result in a thick SEI, which hugely affects Na+ ion transfer and causes higher polarization, ultimately leading to the dramatic decay in capacity and rapid drop in Coulomb efficiency [32,33]. Overall, the evolution process, structure, and composition distribution of SEI, which closely depend on the formulation of electrolyte as well as the electrode selection, critically determine the intrinsic properties of SEI [34]. Hence, the physicochemical characteristics of SEI on HC can be manipulated by adjusting electrolyte constituents, in turn enhancing the electrochemical performance regarding Coulomb efficiency, rate capability, and cycle stability [35]. A bibliometric analysis of the key SEI development in SIBs is carried out based on the SCI database from 2016–2022 (Fig. 1 ). Even though some progress in the research of SEI formation on HC anode has been made, insights into the relationship between SEI manipulation and electrolyte regulation are ambiguous. Besides, there still exists a gap in discussing how to modulate SEI from its properties or formation mechanism by electrolyte engineering, so it is worth teasing out valuable information that provides useful guidance for the feasible SEI buildup. In this review, we devoted our efforts to focusing on the latest research advances of HC anodes in various organic electrolytes and emphasizing the crucial significance of electrolyte design strategies. In particular, the influences of electrolyte solvents, salts, and additives on the SEI establishment are sorted out in detail respectively (Table 2 ). Furthermore, explanations of the SEI formation mechanism in different electrolyte systems are presented. We also put forward critical opinions for the precise design of SEI and conclude with an outlook on existing challenges of studying SEI, which is the urgent need for boosting HC anode application in the commercialization of SIBs. 2 Electrolyte solvents for the formation of SEI In previous studies, ester solvents have gained much attention since their successful application in LIBs. Nevertheless, a desirable SEI characterized by thinness and uniformity is hardly achieved in ester-based electrolytes, which may be partly responsible for the non-ideal cycling and poor rate performance, ultimately hindering their development in SIBs [58]. Unexpectedly, ether solvents show great potential for building a more robust and stable interphase passivating layer [59,60]. Indeed, the electrochemical performance of HC in SIBs has been greatly improved after applying ether solvents. This attracts lots of researchers to reveal the mysteries among ether-based electrolytes, solvation structure, and SEI composition morphology [61,62]. In this section, we mainly discuss the effects of different solvents on SEIs. Based on systemic experiments and thorough analysis, SEI composition is greatly dependent on the solvent types. In the case of NaPF6-EC:DEC and NaPF6-DEGDME electrolytes, Dong et al. [51] found that both SEIs derived from these electrolytes mainly contain organic components. The major organic species within DEGDME-derived SEI, such as RCH2ONa, could lower the Na+ ion diffusion energy barrier. In contrast to the SEI derived from EC:DEC, more inorganic components with low Na+ ion diffusion activation energies spread throughout the DEGDME-derived SEI, like NaF. Further verification by Young’s modulus showed that the DEGDME-derived SEI had better mechanical properties owing to the higher ratio of inorganic components. Additionally, the thinner DEGDME-derived SEI was intuitively seen from HRTEM (high-resolution transmission electron microscopy) images (Fig. 2 a and b), which was in line with the analysis of AFM (atomic force microscopy) (Fig. 3 a and b). From those facts, the DEGDME electrolyte modified the SEI composition, thereby favoring Na storage kinetics. Lv et al. [63] also provided insight into SEIs in DEGDME and EC:DEC electrolytes respectively. Notedly the de-solvent process in DEGDME electrolyte went faster due to the lower de-solvation energy (E des) for DEGDME, which is beneficial for charge transfer kinetic. A thinner SEI in DEGDME electrolyte was generated since its thickness was restricted by the specific structure, where amorphous nano-inorganic species were coated by organic species. Moreover, this amorphous SEI with considerable RCH2ONa, instead of a dense lattice structure, efficiently reduced the Na+ ion diffusion resistance [64]. Conversely, organic and inorganic species within SEI formed in the EC:DEC electrolyte were distributed randomly. In addition to a larger thickness, SEI dispersed with Na2CO3 or NaF crystalline phases is not conducive to Na+ ion diffusion [29], thereby, a larger activation energy for Na+ ion to pass through the SEI (E a, SEI) (Fig. 3c). Nagmani and co-workers used CPME instead of EC together with PC as the electrolyte, producing a more inorganic SEI with higher contents of Na2O, NaCl, and lower O-containing components. This SEI hugely improved ICE and cycling capability compared to the SEI formed in EC: PC electrolyte [65]. Reported research confirmed that the morphology of SEI was affected by electrolyte solvents as well. Bhawana et al. [66] suggested that TEGDME electrolyte was more efficient in creating a thin and homogenous SEI layer. It was intuitively shown that the average thickness of SEI derived from TEGDME was less than that in EC: PC electrolyte (Fig. 2c and d). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results also proved the presence of a thicker SEI and more Na2CO3 and hydrocarbon produced in EC:PC. Ma et al. [67] indicated that inorganic/organic components mixed randomly within the EC:EMC-derived SEI; more importantly, inorganic components dissolved gradually in the EC:EMC electrolyte, which might be responsible for a loose and varying SEI (Fig. 2e). On the contrary, a refined structural SEI in TEGDME electrolyte functioned as the “layer-by-layer SEI” by generating an inorganic inner layer and a fluorinated organic outer layer, to ensure high-quality properties (Fig. 3d). This delicate SEI resulted from TEGDME modification role on the solvation structure of Na+ and PF6 − ions, as well as the different reduction sequences of inorganic/organic complexes. In addition, there existed a “pseudo-SEI” layer that maintained a locally ordered graphite structure for Na+-TEGDME co-intercalation (Fig. 2f), which facilitated Na+ ion transfer and improved the stability of HC electrode. Up to now, more and more explorations of electrolytes have focused on regulating solvation structures. Generally, ether solvents have lower solvating energy than ester solvents, and an electrolyte with weak ion solvation/de-solvation energy has been proposed to be an effective route for manipulating interfacial chemistry [68,69]. THF and Na+ ion formed a weak solvation structure Na+(THF)3.3, thus anions (PF6 −) were more likely to enter the solvated sheath and then reach the HC surface to be reduced. Consequently, a stable anion-derived SEI with an amount of NaF was produced (Fig. 4 a). Moreover, Na+ ion could be de-solvated easily because of the lower binding energy for Na+(THF)3.3, leading to speedy Na+ ion transport kinetics (Fig. 4b). Based on the depth profiles of SEI composition, contents of elements were almost constant, indicating that highly homogeneous SEIs were generated (Fig. 4c–f). Notably, the uniformly distributed NaF was beneficial to the diffusion of Na+ ions [70], whilst the organic-rich SEI provided a higher elasticity and mechanical strength to ensure interface stability. In the EC:DEC/PC electrolytes, a classic multilayer SEI with an organic outer layer and an inorganic inner layer was obtained. However, the content of NaF was relatively low on the surface and then increased with the etching depth, which was detrimental to ionic conductivity. It is worth mentioning that having a full understanding of the solvent’s nature does well in the modulation of solvation structure. For instance, the compact coordination shell effectively impeded the interaction of the contact ion pair (PF6 − and Na+) due to the low polarity and higher flexibility of diglyme [71,72]. Consequently, interactions between PF6 − and HC surface were reduced, and far fewer decompositions resulted in a thinner SEI layer. Moreover, since diglyme had a lower reduction potential than NaPF6, the preferential decomposition of anion (PF6 −) led to the formation of an inner SEI layer with rich NaF (Fig. 4g). As proven, both bands of Na2CO3 and C=O kept extremely weak through etching depth, indicating a thin and homogenous SEI layer with a very small amount of organic products. On the contrary, bulky solvation shells in EC:DEC electrolyte together with the easier reduced EC:DEC solvents resulted in a large amount of organic components, thereby a thick SEI, with polyester complexes mainly distributed at the interior while Na2CO3 dispersed at the exterior, showed huge resistivity (Fig. 5 a). Herein, Alptekin’s group concluded that ether-based electrolyte favored cycling stability once the first fluorine-rich SEI layer was formed because of its capability of maintaining interphase integrity [73]. Conversely, the ester-based electrolyte had a detrimental role in long-term stability accompanied by the growth of interfacial resistance. The instability of SEI layer could be improved by tailoring the solvation structure to reduce SEI components’ solubility in electrolytes and induce more insoluble components (Fig. 5b and c) [54]. Specifically, the low-polar TFP solvent with a low dielectric constant minimized the degree of SEI dissolution compared to other ester solvents, meanwhile, DMC was added to compensate for ionic conductivity. More significantly, the solvation structure can be modulated to reduce the number of free solvent molecules, leading to a decrease in the solubility of SEI components (Fig. 6 a and b). The pathway of electrolyte decomposition could also be adjusted by modifying solvation structures to produce more insoluble components within the SEI layer. Typically, the decomposition of electrolyte salt (NaFSI) rather than solvent induced an inorganic-rich SEI with less solubility. Herein, due to the advantage of forming the stable interphase, HC anode in the advanced low-solvation electrolyte (NaFSI-TFP: DMC) exhibited remarkable rate capability and long cycling performance. From the discussions above, it is necessary to highlight the importance of selecting electrolyte solvents since a suitable solvent critically impacts the formation of SEI. With explorations on electrolyte solvents and SEI, we obtained lots of valuable information. Obviously, many of the present ether solvents show more advantages than ester solvents based on those experimental analyses. For instance, the regulating function of ether solvents is crucially important in light of adjusting the solvation structure and the pathway of electrolyte decomposition, further modifying SEI composition or morphology. It is more likely to generate a thinner and more uniform SEI by utilizing ether solvents. Additionally, some solvents with special characteristics, such as low polarity, also benefit SEI formation. However, there still exist some difficulties to be overcome in the future. SEI mainly contains organic and inorganic species, but controversy exists regarding the content of each species that is beneficial to the properties of SEI. More research is needed to elucidate whether the organic-rich SEI or inorganic-rich SEI is more favorable. Besides, how to judge the degree of loose or compact for SEIs is not clear and there is no advanced technology to prove this because of the limited characterization methods. Thoroughly comprehending the influence of solvation structure such as tuning the routes of electrolyte decomposition and improving the stability of SEI will provide more useful electrolyte design principles. To combat those, researchers not only need to efficiently use in-situ and advanced structural, microstructural, and electrochemical characterization techniques but also apply theoretical methods or simulation models. Besides, more in-depth studies should be conducted to develop more advanced characterization techniques. After doing those, it may open a new avenue in understanding and tuning the properties of SEI on the HC anode for SIBs applications. 3 Electrolyte salts for the formation of SEI Sodium salt has been reported to have a profound influence on SEI composition and evolution process. For instance, the type of anions plays a critical role in determining the decomposition routes of electrolytes, and the salt concentration also largely defines the SEI components [74,75]. Of note, the solvation structure, especially the coordination and chemical environment of solvent molecules, presents an evident change after adding the specific sodium salt, thereby impacting the formation of SEI [76]. In the following part, we will discuss the prominently utilized electrolyte salts in detail. In-depth studies of different salts, especially salt anions, provide another insight into the variability of SEI compositions. Alptekin et al. studied the dissociation pathway of salt anions and found that the generated fragments made the HC surface intermediately functionalized [73]. Specifically, ClO4 − dissociated by gradual loss of oxygen while for PF6 −, fluorine fragments were stepwise detached (Fig. 6c). Moreover, F had a higher tendency to be adsorbed on the HC surface and then seemed to form F–C bonds that made the basal plane wrinkled, but a favorable F–C bond is beneficial for the passivating effect. Subsequently, the dimer of Na–Cl or Na–F formed once Cl or F was desorbed from the HC surface. Note that the lower dissociation barrier of ClO4 − led to its faster decomposition and continuous reaction with Na+ ions. Thus, the irreversible sodium depletion happened, which was not limited to the basal plane. Besides, ClO4 − anions could continually interact with the active HC surface, resulting in a non-compact and thick SEI with large resistivity (Fig. 4g), and thus a greater capacity fade occurred. However, the interaction between Na+ ions and fragments derived from the PF6 − decomposition happened at the HC surface. This led to a slower consumption of Na+ ions and thus a thinner SEI layer. Additionally, the production of NaF, which was mainly distributed at the inner NaPF6-derived SEI, not only contributed to the conductivity but also benefited the protective ability of SEI to prolong the stability of HC anode. Eshetu et al. pointed out that the different contents of organic ingredients with –C=O or –C–O resulted from the reductions of EC and DEC, which were hindered by a preferentially formed salt-derived passivation layer at the higher potential [26]. Moreover, the species of organic components, arising from solvent decompositions, decreased in the following order: NaPF6 > NaClO4 ≈ NaTFSI > NaFTFSI > NaFSI. For components at the interior SEI layer, the NaF content hugely relied on the difference of X–F (S–F/P–F/C–F) bond liability. Analysis revealed that thinner SEIs in NaPF6/NaTFSI-electrolyte and a thicker SEI derived from NaClO4-electrolyte were obtained, respectively. They also found that the SEI layer was more homogeneous and richer in organic species upon applying sodium salts compared to lithium salts. Additionally, Le et al. suggested that the SEIs in the case of NaBF4/NaOTf/NaPF6-TEGDME electrolyte contained a higher proportion of inorganic components and fewer organic components, which guaranteed outstanding cycling performance and remarkable rate capability [77]. Nevertheless, HC anodes in NaFSI/NaTFSI/NaClO4-electrolyte displayed the worst cycling performance due to unstable SEIs. The salt concentration is another key parameter that greatly affects the formation of SEI layer. Interestingly, an appropriately low NaPF6 concentration (0.2 M) contributed to forming the discontinuous-passivation layer, since the contact ion pairs existed fewer at low salt concentrations and the products from electrolyte decomposition were not enough to generate an intact SEI (Fig. 7 ) [78]. In turn, a continuous SEI layer formed at high salt concentrations hampered the Na+-DGM co-insertion, leading to partial capacity loss during co-insertion. Besides, changes in the concentration of NaTFSI (0.5 M−5 M) directly caused fluctuations in elemental contents of the HC surface as shown in Fig. 8 (a) [79]. With the increased NaTFSI concentration, the content of O element reduced, namely a decrease of components that contained C=O and C–O, which was harmful to Na+ ions diffusion and de-solvation. Meanwhile, the contents of F/S/N increased due to the increment of NaTFSI concentration but became lower in 5 M NaTFSI electrolyte compared to 4 M NaTFSI, which was consistent with the changes in rate capability. It is worth mentioning that SEI components with F/S/N elements derived from NaTFSI decomposition are conducive to protecting the HC electrode [80]. Conversely, ester solvent decomposition (EC:DMC) produced large amounts of carbon compounds involving Na2CO3 and NaCO3R that participated in the SEI formation. Manipulating the solvation structure to weaken Coulombic interactions between anions and Na+ ions can influence the evolution of SEI [81]. It was found that the tight coordination of Na+ ions and solvents kept Na+ and PF6 − ions far away, resulting in a weak Coulombic interaction between solvated Na+ and PF6 −, thereby faster Na+ ions migration in NaPF6-based electrolyte (Fig. 8b). Besides, PF6 − in the solvated outer layer was preferentially reduced on the HC surface to form a NaF-rich inner SEI layer. Then organic species originated from the solvent reduction deposited on the outer SEI layer. More significantly, the less gas (C2H4, C2H6, CH4) generated from solvents further indicated that this stratified SEI layer could restrain electrolyte decomposition and protect the HC anode efficiently. However, ClO4 − was close to Na+ in the solvation structure, so it appeared around Na+ ion more frequently, which caused a stronger Coulombic interaction and a slower migration of Na+-solvent clusters. Finally, the higher desolvation energy barrier and larger ionic transfer resistances slowed down Na storage kinetics in the NaClO4 electrolyte. A mosaic model structure with the uneven distribution of inorganic/organic species stemmed from the reduction of EC and ClO4 − at the same potential (∼0.8 V). For this section, substantial work related to electrolyte salts has been discussed. Researchers tried various electrolyte salts to achieve the improvement of the electrochemical performance of HC anode. Indeed, the electrolyte salt governs the SEI formation on the surface of HC from either the anion types or the salt concentration to some degree. Different salts applied in electrolytes not only impact the species of organic or inorganic ingredients but also the contents of various components. Besides, salt concentration as a crucial factor is closely associated with the whole creating process of SEI. Based on those perspectives, selecting an appropriate electrolyte salt is significantly important. However, further research is needed to deal with some complicated tasks urgently. For example, a more accurate and comprehensive analysis of the relationship between electrolyte salt and the production of inorganic/organic species should be executed. Generally, most researchers concluded that the inorganic species came from the decomposition of electrolyte salt, while studies show that electrolyte salt has a huge impact on the organic species that originate from solvents. Moreover, inorganic/organic species have a huge difference in different literature even using the same electrolyte for HC anode. From this point of view, clarifying the compatibility of solvents and salts may be beneficial for unraveling this puzzle. More rigorous experimental approaches and more accurate instruments need to be used to reduce errors. We could expect that the thickness of SEI may be more controllable if the proportion of organic and inorganic species is clear, further precisely tailoring the high-quality SEI. 4 Electrolyte additives for the formation of SEI Apart from solvents and salts, the incorporation of additives is also vital to improve the properties of pristine electrolytes [82]. Fortunately, based on the experience of LIBs, researchers continually conducted a series of functional additives explorations for SIBs. There is no doubt that those explorations laid the groundwork for appropriately designing electrolytes to form a stable SEI layer. Currently, the most commonly used electrolyte additives are FEC and VC, which have been discussed from the perspective of SEI compositions, structure, and solvation structure [25,83]. Other additives have also been investigated, varying considerably in functions. Until now, many works have emphasized the importance of electrolyte additives on SEI compositional changes. The effects of NaPF6-based electrolytes with and without additives added (3% FEC or 3% DMCF) have been reported [47]. It revealed that the SEI layer with specific components, such as sodium ethylene dicarbonate and NaF, had outperformed electrochemical behaviors, whereas either low content of NaF or high content of Na2CO3 was related to the inferior performance. The NaF content with FEC added was 10 times higher compared to the free additive of electrolyte, and a proper ratio of NaF was responsible for the SEI stability (Fig. 8c). For sodium ethylene dicarbonate, its content reduced from 45 at% to 30 at% which mainly resulted from the increment of NaF and aliphatic chains. In contrast, with the addition of DMCF, the SEI composition changed crucially by forming a larger amount of Na2CO3 (75 at%), which was verified by XPS analysis, leading to a relatively thick SEI layer (Fig. 8d). It suggested that the DMCF additive had a detrimental role in electrochemical performance concerning ICE and reversible capacity. In another work, Kim et al. [84] elucidated in depth the thermal stability of HC anode at a higher temperature due to the thermally robust SEI in NaPF6-EC:DEC-SA electrolyte (Fig. 9 a). A NaF-rich SEI in the FEC-based electrolyte could restrain electrolyte salt decomposition to some degree but its thickness crucially increased in contrast to the addition of free or SA additives, therefore a larger resistance. Nevertheless, the SA-derived SEI with large proportions of Na2CO3 and sodium alkyl carbonate was more effective in enhancing the SEI thermal stability than the FEC-derived SEI [85]. Most significantly, SA-derived SEI was able to suppress salt decomposition, which was demonstrated by the marginal increase of F 1s and P 2p peaks. Herein, HC anode still displayed excellent performance even at higher temperatures. Note that considering the intrinsic nature of additive is more likely to exert its functions. For example, 15-C-5 (15-Crown-5) was more stable than solvent molecules in light of its lower HOMO energy level and higher LOMO energy level (Fig. 9b), thus, it was difficult to participate in the formation of SEI [86]. Besides, the oxygen of 15-C-5 was highly capable of coordinating with Na+ ion and the coordination compounds subsequently reached the surface of HC to modify SEI. 15-C-5 effectively prevented solvent molecules from continual interaction with HC anode but had little effect on the migration of Na+ and ClO4 − ions to the HC surface. Hence, this increased the content of inorganic species but decreased that of organic species within the SEI, which resulted in a uniform and smooth SEI (Fig. 9c). However, intuitive changes in SEI revealed that cracks and dendritic deposits emerged after cycling in the case of free additives. Moreover, adding an additive to induce a desirable structure of SEI is a feasible approach. When the additive PP14 was added to the NaFSI-EC:DEC electrolyte, an almost intact “layer-by-layer” SEI with the “pseudo” SEI was produced. Introducing the larger cation (N-methyl piperidine cation) from PP14 impacted the solvation structure between FSI− anions and Na+ ions, which changed the inorganic/organic complexes’ reduction sequence (Fig. 10 a) [87]. Analysis showed that inorganic species were mainly deposited at the inner layer of SEI while the organic ingredients were mostly at the outer layer. Simultaneously, a resembling graphitized structure on the HC surface was promoted by the PP14 additive, which was conducive to the faster transmission of Na+ ions. By contrast, the SEI in a “formation-consumption” process led to the random distribution of inorganic/organic matters without PP14, therefore, an unstable and irregular SEI was formed. The interaction between additives and salts, especially with anions, cannot be ignored. Indeed, the weak Coulombic interaction between Na+ and PF6 − ion facilitated FEC to enter into the solvated shell [81]. Hence, a higher concentration of FEC with the lower LUMO in the solvation structure enabled FEC to be preferentially reduced after the decomposition of PF6 − ion, producing a large amount of NaF and fewer organic species. Conversely, FEC hardly entered the solvated shell owing to the strong interaction of Na+ and CIO4 − ions (Fig. 8b), which led to a lower concentration of FEC within the solvated shell, and thus the decomposition voltage of FEC was decreased to the same as that of solvent, forming a thicker mosaic SEI with NaF mixed. Furthermore, Lin et al. [90] introduced the TTFEB additive as an anion acceptor to inhibit the ring-opening polymerization of DOL in NaPF6-DOL:DGM electrolyte by anchoring PF6 − anion, which effectively suppressed the decrease in ionic conductivity. Moreover, since the TTFEB additive was preferentially reduced, an inorganic-rich SEI with a large amount of NaF and Na2O was obtained. In contrast, the C and O peaks’ intensities of organic components became weaker, which meant fewer organic components within the SEI. The stronger bulk signal of HC after cycling in TTFEB-based electrolyte implied a thinner SEI which enabled Na+ ions to rapidly migrate. Nevertheless, the concentrations of both organic and inorganic components of SEI layer were relatively high in the TTFEB-free electrolyte, especially for the content of organic components, suggesting that an organic-rich while less compact SEI was formed. Overall, the utilization of additives somewhat determines the compositions and structure of SEI according to the above discussions. Generally, a homogeneous and thick SEI is conducive to facilitating the diffusion of Na+ ions, further promoting the performance of HC anode. The incorporation of an additive could adjust the solvation structure and the sequence of electrolyte decomposition. Additionally, some specific chemical components will undergo drastic changes, such as the content of NaF after introducing EFC, when compared to free additives. More notably, the additives’ nature and the interplay among additives, salts, and solvents are crucially important. Unfortunately, the research on electrolyte additives in SIBs is still in its infancy, and existing research gaps need to be filled. For example, the positive effect of Na2CO3 is controversial, and it is unclear whether the content of Na2CO3 or organic species dominates the thickness of SEI. Most importantly, the compatibility of solvents, salts, and additives or their reaction mechanism should be studied in depth, which is the key process to determine SEI. As research continues, the future direction should be focused on understanding the underlying roles of additives that play in the SEI formation mechanism. Besides those strategies of manipulating electrolytes, other innovative methods like making an artificial coating layer or using interfacial catalysis to engineer the SEI have been implemented, which worked well with homogenous SEIs formed (Fig. 10b and c) [88,89]. 5 Current characterization techniques of electrolyte and SEI Some fundamental electrochemical techniques, such as potentiodynamic/galvanodynamic/impedance-based techniques corresponding to cyclic voltammetry (CV)/galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD)/electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), are commonly used to analyze redox-reactions and test the reversible capacity, cycling stability, and kinetics [91,92]. With the development of characterization techniques, more and more advanced methods even emerging in-situ techniques such as in-situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) and in-situ Raman spectroscopy are applied in this field [93]. However, characterization techniques for direct observation and precise quantitative analysis are not yet mature. In this section, it summarizes the currently used techniques for exploring electrolytes and SEIs including characterization methodologies, theoretical calculations, and simulations. 5.1 Characterization methodologies of electrolyte (In-situ) Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and (in-situ) Raman spectroscopy is usually employed to capture information on the bond vibration, which could reflect the coordination states in the electrolyte such as solvation behavior [94]. FTIR has the advantage of investigating organic groups, but the absorption peaks are susceptible to interference. Raman spectroscopy analysis, with high sensitivity, can be implemented to decipher the chemical environment of either organic electrolyte or aqueous electrolyte, especially for reflecting the information of inorganic species. Hence, choosing the suitable spectroscopy should depend on the specific electrolyte [95]. (In-situ) Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) is another effective method to clarify the solvation structure in various electrolytes, analyzing the chemical environment of Na+/anions/solvent molecules, and further elucidating their structure [96]. 5.2 Characterization methodology of SEIs Having a good understanding of SEI composition and structure in different electrolyte systems is extremely essential. Morphological investigations are conducted by different transmission electron microscopy (TEM) or cryo-electron microscopy. For instance, the thickness and crystallites of SEI are evaluated by HRTEM images, and more details can be obtained by high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) images or energy dispersive X-ray scanning TEM (STEM-EDX) elemental mapping [97]. Combined with argon-ion etching at different depths, XPS is carried out to detect elements’ concentration and analyze the chemical composition distribution, finally identifying the structural evolution of SEIs. Moreover, AFM could quantify the mechanical properties of SEI by measuring the average Young's modulus of SEI [98]. 5.3 Theoretical calculations and simulations By virtue of theoretical calculations and simulations, the solvation structure dynamics and the formation or properties of SEI layer are in-depth explored. Currently, the most commonly employed methods are density functional theory (DFT), molecular dynamics (MD), and the ab-initio molecular dynamics (AIMD). DFT calculation has been widely used to describe charge distributions or calculate the energy band gaps of solvent and additive molecules, and further analyze interactions between electrolyte components [99]. In most cases, it is combined with other methods for comprehensive analysis. For instance, DFT together with (in-situ) EIS evaluates the de-solvation energy barrier and the ionic transport impedances [81]. Molecular dynamics (MD) is a significant method to reveal the solvation structure and analyze dynamic behaviors, which is beneficial for understanding the mechanism of SEI formation [100]. Recently, a hybrid method including MD and MC (Monte Carlo), called Red Moon methodology (RM), shows great applicability in describing SEI formation [101]. Besides, especially the ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) with higher accuracy, is performed to investigate the Na+ ion diffusion and transport. Overall, the existence of these calculations and simulations has greatly advanced SEI exploration. One of the crucial aspects that limit the current research is the existing techniques for characterization. Herein, advanced and intuitive techniques should be designed and implemented to decipher SEI's formation and structure. Besides, making full use of the in-situ and operando characterizations to observe the whole process in real time, such as monitoring structural or interface changes, is one of useful approaches. At the same time, theoretical calculations and simulations are also quite necessary. We need to appropriately combine various characterization methods with theoretical calculations or computational simulations to gain an understanding of the relationship between SEIs and electrolyte composition, which promotes quantitative analysis, finally precisely controlling the properties of SEI. Anyway, this may seem like a daunting task, but it could be achievable with our persistence and efforts. 6 Conclusions and perspectives Exploring advanced electrode materials is the key to the operational stability of SIBs. Hard carbon outperforms most electrode materials owing to its distinct advantages. The electrochemical performance of HC anode is certain to some extent reliant on the characteristics of SEI. An ideal SEI maintains a satisfactory passivation effect, effectively protects electrodes, and facilitates ion kinetics. However, the formation mechanism of SEI on the HC surface has not been fully unveiled. Immense efforts should be continuously made to elucidate the interplay between HC anodes and electrolytes from a dynamic perspective and provide strong support for optimizing the formation of SEI. In summary, the electrolyte is closely related to the formation mechanism of SEI. We present current works and elaborate on the influence of electrolyte solvents, salts, and additives on the electrochemical performance of SIBs (Table 3 ). Specifically, for SEI structure, the stratified form, mainly determined by solvents and salts, offers obvious advantages in terms of structural stability, and ion transfer capability compared to a random distribution. Regarding rapid ion transport kinetics, a compact and thin SEI layer is better than a loose and thick SEI layer. Besides, electrolyte salts bring huge differences in the SEI compositions especially the types or contents of inorganic/organic species due to the specific reduction order. Note that the presence of NaF derived from salt or additive decomposition is conducive to ion diffusion and organic species improve the mechanical strength of SEI to guarantee long cycling performance. Moreover, with respect to the evolution process of SEI, the connection of anions and solvents is significantly important, affecting the solvation structure and further determining the decomposition route and products. From those results, the optimum formula of electrolyte needs to be deeply explored. Nevertheless, despite considerable research being done, certain challenges of tailoring a satisfactory SEI remain in the practical application of HC anode for SIBs. More effort should be paid to overcome those challenges and realize the commercial potential of HC anode in SIBs. (1) The thickness is normally measured by HRTEM, which might not be the most accurate measurement method and there is no advanced technique to define the compact or loose properties of SEI, nor the evaluation criteria. (2) Furthermore, the role of compositions such as the presence of Na2CO3 is not fully understood. (3) The contents and types of inorganic/organic species should be precisely analyzed, which is beneficial for providing useful guidance to control the thickness of SEI. (4) The reaction between the electrolyte and HC anode, especially the sequence and process of reaction in which solvents, salts, and additives are involved, should be elucidated clearly. (5) More advanced characterization techniques are needed to accurately identify HC surface chemicals and intuitively detect the contents of compositions. Deep research should be paid for quantitative analysis of electrolyte solvent, salt, and additive’s effects on the SEI formation and thus precisely control the SEI structure. Based on the above issues, we need a rational direction to guide our further investigations of tailoring the ideal SEI for the HC anode application. How to achieve the controllability of SEI composition and thickness is one of the most critical technical difficulties for ensuring SEI properties, further improving the performance of HC anode. More efforts should be focused on those studies. The details are as follows: firstly, a good knowledge of the intrinsic nature of solvents, salts, and additives from their physical and chemical properties, even their compatibility, will lay the foundation for electrolyte engineering. Furthermore, the most important and difficult step is to fully understand the electrolyte and electrode's reaction sequence and microscopic reaction mechanism, which is closely related to SEI's components, structure, and properties. More precisely quantitative analysis of products within SEI in terms of the inorganic/organic complexes and the contents is needed. Combined with theoretical calculations such as the density functional theory (DFT), designing advanced techniques such as implementing simulation will be helpful in predicting the reactions and revealing the dynamic evolution of SEIs. All these provide a strong basis for the future SEI design to match HC materials and manufacture high-performance batteries. Lu Liu works at Hubei Three Gorges Polytechnic and is currently a Ph.D. candidate at Universiti Malaya. Her research focuses on the design of high-performance electrolytes and electrode materials for sodium-ion batteries. Lingling Xiao is currently an associate professor atHubei Three Gorges Polytechnic and she has extensive experience in energy conversion and storage. Zhi Sun works as an associate professor at Hubei Three Gorges Polytechnic. Her current research interest is renewable energy storage and conversion, including lithium-ion batteries and sodium-ion batteries. Shahid Bashir joined UMPEDAC in 2022 as a Senior Lecturer. He is working on electrode and electrolyte materials for energy storage devices and performed excellently in research where he published 110 research articles in high-ranked Journals. Ramesh Kasi works as an associate professor in Universiti Malaya. His research focuses on polymeric materials for electrochemical applications. He has published more than 200 research papers in reputed journals. Yonghong Gu has devoted his efforts to fabricating high-performing electrodes and high-safety electrolytes for advanced energy storage devices. He participated in several research programs and won many awards. Ramesh T Subramaniam is a material scientist well known for his outstanding contribution to rechargeable energy storage technologies. The novelty of his research is the successful invention of advanced electrolytes and electrodes for green energy devices. He has received many international and national awards and was recognized as a TWAS Fellow by the World Academy of Sciences (TWAS) in 2023.

coredata.dc:description: Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have great potential to be the next major energy storage devices due to their obvious advantages and developing advanced electrodes and electrolytes is urgently necessary to promote its future industrialization. However, hard carbon as a state-of-the-art anode of SIBs still suffers from the low initial Coulomb efficiency and unsatisfactory rate capability, which could be improved by forming desirable solid electrolyte interphases (SEI) to some extent. Indeed, the chemistry and morphology of these interfacial layers are fundamental parameters affecting the overall battery operation, and optimizing the electrolyte to dictate the quality of SEI on hard carbon is a key strategy. Hence, this review summarizes the recent research on SEI design by electrolyte manipulation from solvents, salts, and additives. It also presents some potential mechanisms of SEI formation in various electrolyte systems. Besides, the current advanced characterization techniques for electrolyte and SEI structure analyses have been comprehensively discussed. Lastly, current challenges and future perspectives of SEI formation on hard carbon anode for SIBs are provided from the viewpoints of its compositions, evolution processes, structures, and characterization techniques, which will promote SEI efficient manipulation and improve the performance of hard carbon, and further contribute to the development of SIBs.

coredata.dc:title: Rational manipulation of electrolyte to induce homogeneous SEI on hard carbon anode for sodium-ion battery
